title: VOLUT: Efficient Volumetric Streaming Enhanced by LUT-Based Super-Resolution
author: Chendong Wang (University of Wisconsin–Madison), Anlan Zhang (University of Southern California), Yifan Yang (Microsoft Research Asia), Lili Qiu (Microsoft Research Asia), Yuqing Yang (Microsoft Research Asia), Xinyang Jiang (Microsoft Research Asia), Feng Qian (University of Southern California), Suman Banerjee (University of Wisconsin–Madison), ...
relevance_why: This paper discusses volumetric video streaming, which could inform similar techniques in audio-visual synchronization and enhancement tasks.
background: Efficiently streaming volumetric video content involves reducing bandwidth while maintaining high visual quality through super-resolution techniques that upscale low-resolution data.
contribution: This paper introduces VoLUT, a system leveraging lookup tables to enhance volumetric video streaming, achieving a 70% reduction in bandwidth usage and 36.7% improvement in quality of experience.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous volumetric streaming solutions struggled with high computational demands and prolonged latency, particularly when using neural network-based super-resolution.
technical_comparison.novelty: VoLUT simplifies super-resolution into a two-stage process that uses efficient interpolation and lookup tables, significantly accelerating the process and reducing resource consumption.

key_innovation: The method utilizes lookup tables for refinement, drastically reducing computational requirements and ensuring fast, real-time performance on mobile devices.
real_world_impact: This approach not only enhances the viewing experience for volumetric video but also opens avenues for developing low-latency immersive applications in virtual reality and augmented reality.

new_terms.volumetric video: **Volumetric video** captures a 3D space, allowing users to engage with the video from multiple perspectives instead of a fixed viewpoint.
new_terms.lookup table (LUT): **Lookup table (LUT)** is a data structure that maps input values to output values, used here to streamline computation in super-resolution tasks.
